title: 107_s2881
content: Section 139A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces the exclusion from income of employer homeownership assistance under home ownership assistance programs. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for the exclusion of employer-provided homeownership assistance from an eligible employee's gross income. The assistance must be part of a homeownership assistance program described in the code, and the maximum exclusion amount is 10 percent of the maximum principal obligation for a mortgage insured under the National Housing Act. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for the exclusion of employer-provided homeownership assistance from an eligible employee's gross income. A homeownership assistance program is a written plan by an employer for all employees, providing assistance that meets specific requirements. Eligible employees are those with adjusted gross income below a certain threshold. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for exclusion of employer-provided homeownership assistance for eligible employees based on income thresholds. Dollar amounts for individuals in different categories are specified, with adjustments for cost-of-living after 2003. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows exclusion of employer-provided homeownership assistance for eligible employees based on income thresholds. Dollar amounts are specified for individuals with adjustments for cost-of-living after 2003. The term 'first-time homebuyer' is defined. The term 'first-time homebuyer' is defined as an individual who had no ownership in a principal residence in the local area for 2 years prior to purchasing the current residence. This designation can only be used once per individual, and the principal residence must not exceed a certain purchase price. The term 'homeownership assistance' refers to aid used for qualified acquisition costs on a principal residence in the local area, provided before the 120th day. The assistance must be used for costs related to constructing, reconstructing, altering, repairing, or improving a residence, with payments made before specific deadlines. Financing assistance provided under homeownership programs involving loans may be treated as homeownership assistance. If a loan is discharged after a required period of service, the assistance is considered provided at the time of discharge. The local area for an employee's residence is within 50 miles of their workplace. The term 'employee' excludes self-employed individuals. Utilization rates of homeownership assistance types do not affect program compliance. No deduction or credit allowed for excluded amounts from income. Basis of residence reduced by exclusion amount. Amendment to reporting requirements for certain fringe benefit plans. Conforming amendments made to subchapter B of the Internal Revenue Code. The table of sections for part III of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by inserting a new item after section 139. Section 1016 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include adjustments to basis for residences where income was excluded under section 139A. These amendments apply to taxable years starting December 31, 2002.
